Award.AwardTitle: Neutrino-Less Double Beta Decay with EXO-200 and EXO
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides base support for the group to continue to participate in the Enriched Xenon Observatory (EXO) program to search for neutrino-less double beta decay in 136-Xenon, a nuclear process which could hold clues into the nature of neutrinos. Observation of this decay would imply that neutrinos are Majorana particles, i.e. their own antiparticles, with profound implications on our understanding of the pattern of masses of fundamental particles and of the structure and evolution of the early universe.

The EXO-200 experiment, a 200-kg enriched liquid xenon detector is now running underground at the Waste Isolation Pilot Plant (WIPP) in New Mexico. This group will also take part in the development and design of a more sensitive tonne-scale EXO experiment (full-EXO) to follow EXO-200. With the planned research at UMass, the group will provide key input to the design of a full-EXO experiment with sensitivity to neutrino masses as small as 10 meV by: i) optimizing the optical response and VUV detection efficiency of the detector, and ii) supplying a single Barium ion source, a possibly game-changing tool for the realization of the EXO-specific background suppression scheme which looks for the appearance of Barium ions following 136-Xe double beta decay.

Broader Impacts: Noble liquid detectors are finding applications in medical imaging devices as well as in remote monitoring of nuclear power plant fuel composition. The ultra-low background methods developed for detectors like EXO-200 have taken radioactive contamination to levels considered impossible to achieve just twenty years ago. Processes of interest for the electronics industry now require similar levels of radio-purity in their manufacturing lines. Work with EXO-200 and EXO provides ample opportunities for graduate students to perform cutting edge research and experience working in a medium-sized international scientific collaboration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award covered the activities carried out by the UMass Amherst group on the EXO-200 experiment (EXO = Enriched Xenon Observatory), running since 2011 at the WIPP site in New Mexico to search for neutrino-less double beta decay (DBD) of the xenon-136 nucleus. Neutrino-less double beta decay is a nuclear decay whose existence would imply that neutrinos are fundamental Majorana fermions, i.e. identical to anti-neutrinos, their antimatter counterparts. The decay violates lepton number conservation and together with CP-non-conservation, would provide key input in support of leptogenesis theories of the matter-antimatter asymmetry in the Universe. EXO-200 uses 175 kg of liquefied xenon (enriched to 80% in the 136 isotope) in a double, liquid xenon time projection chamber (TPC) [1].

 

After discovering the standard 2-neutrino DBD of Xe-136 in 2011 (before the period covered by this award [2]), the EXO-200 experiment has produced ten more papers under the period covered by this grant. These include: i) two papers setting lower limits on the half-life for neutrino-less double beta decay of Xe-136 [3,4], the third best sensitivity for this decay (the best when [3] was published); ii) a search for 0-neutrino DBD with emission of Majoron particles [5]; iii) a refinement of the measurement of the half-life for 2-neutrino double beta decay of Xe-136 [6], which is the slowest 2-neutrino DBD for all isotopes investigated experimentally, and interestingly the most accurately measured; iv) a search for DBD of Xe-136 to excited states of Ba-136 [7]; a detailed study of the main backgrounds for EXO-200, including gamma/beta emitters [8], muon-induced radioactivity [9], and radon-related alpha and beta emitters and their ionization fraction in liquid xenon [10]; a search for Lorentz-violation in DBD [11].

 

The UMass group has contributed very substantially to operating EXO-200 and getting it up and running following the forced 2-year shutdown due to accidents at WIPP (unrelated to EXO-200), with postdoc Tim Daniels, PI Andrea Pocar, senior scientist Krishna Kumar, and graduate students Sereres Johnston and Sara Feyzbakhsh. Responsibilities of UMass personnel spanned from EXO-200 detector management, operations, and shifts (on- and off-site) to data analysis (Tim Daniels, who is currently at SLAC, is now EXO-200 Technical Manager). Sereres Johnston was one lead graduate student for [7], and defended her Ph.D. thesis in Summer 2016.

EXO-200, the first 100-kg scale DBD detector to produce scientific results, is now running again with upgraded hardware and the goal to perform a more sensitive search for 0-neutrino DBD of Xe-136 over the coming years. The work and manpower leading the the restart of the experiment were in part covered by this award.

 

While EXO-200 was running, the EXO laboratory at UMass ran tests of photo-detectors, large area avalanche photodiodes (LAAPDs) and silicon photomultipliers (SiPMs) at 170 K in vacuum and liquefied xenon. LAAPDs are the detectors used to measure scintillation flashes in EXO-200, while SiPMs are the choice for a future, follow-up nEXO experiment. This activity was, in part, covered by this award. The PI has a top-tier role in the nEXO organization, for which he is in charge of developing a suitably ultra-low background TPC. The UMass group has been the first within nEXO to run SiPMs in liquid xenon (LXe), and plans to carry out SiPM characterizations as well as measure the reflectivity of VUV light in LXe. Key SiPM research at UMass was mostly  performed by student/technician Jacopo Dalmasson [12] (now a graduate student at Stanford), with the PI and a team of undergraduates.

 

The EXO-200/nEXO group at UMass has involved a large number of undergraduate students, with well-above-average representation from under-represented minorities. Results obtained under this award were published in peer-reviewed journals and presented at national and international conferences.
